title: If you could only choose one song to play every time you walked into a room for the rest of your life, what would it be? - Quora

response.answer_text: Freddy's Dead by Curtis Mayfield But it wouldn't just be when I enter the room the music starts playing. Oh no no no. The opening riff of the song will just come out of nowhere. Smoke and shit starts rising from the floor. 5 seconds ago, your boring wife or girlfriend was sitting next to you. You look back over and she done turned into some throwback chick from a blaxploitation film. Those “Wanta Fanta" chicks show up dancing and pandering Fanta. And about time Curtis hits that first line… soon as he goes, “Freddy's dead….. that's what I said" I done stepped in the room like BLAM!! Pose on em…. Then I step off and go about my day. But that's only on the weekdays. On the weekend, ots a whole different groove. Same scenario, except now The Look Of Love by Issac Hayes is playing. I'm talking the 10 minute instrumental intro before he even starts singing version. Dig it: I'm already standing inside the frame of the door. Just checking the scene. No one has even paid attention or looked up to see me or anyone for that matter standing there. But the first person who does, that's when the music starts. Which prompts every one to look by this point. And if you know the songs then you know how it starts all light then the horns and drums. And I just float thru and continue about my day. OMG close your eyes can you see it lol… Its so player.

It seems like you’d need any number of entry-songs, depending on what you are entering, the occasion, and even your own mood or attitude. All of which just gives me the opportunity to name more than one song… ;>) My “Hail To The Chief” fanfare would be Gerry Rafferty’s “Baker Street”, the most grandiose rock tune I know.  For more routine entrances, where a more easy-going expression is appropriate, maybe “Forever Young”, by Chris Isaak.  It’s early evening, the night is about to begin as I enter: “La Vie Dansante”, by Aaron Neville.  For outdoor occasions, Chet Atkins and Tommy Emmanuel’s beautiful version of Julian Lennon’s “Saltwater”.  When I’m feeling low-down and blue, I’d choose “Everybody Needs Love”, by Drive-by Truckers.  My “No-Entry” song, which in truth, would be the one playing on repeat most or the day back at home, is Joan Armatrading’s “Me, Myself I”.
